senses.de: The plan for how to spend money
senses.ex: The company has a tight budget for this project

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Sometimes 'budget' is used metaphorically for time or other resources that need managing.
Tips.example: You'll need to budget your time wisely to prepare for the exam.

Tips.title: Prioritize Spending
Tips.description: 'Budget' implies prioritizing some areas over others due to limited funds.
Tips.example: Our budget focuses on marketing more than development.

Tips.title: Budget Cuts
Tips.description: Discussing budget often involves the concept of 'cuts', or reductions in spending.
Tips.example: The new manager made significant budget cuts.

senses.de: The money that is available to an organization and that is planned to be spent
senses.ex: His department is getting a larger share of the budget

Tips.title: Funding Allocation
Tips.description: A budget often details how funds are allocated to different departments or needs.
Tips.example: The budget allocated more to research this year.

Tips.title: Fiscal Year
Tips.description: An annual budget is usually aligned with a company's or government's fiscal year.
Tips.example: The annual budget is prepared every fiscal year.

Tips.title: Budget Surplus & Deficit
Tips.description: A budget might result in 'surplus' (extra funds) or 'deficit' (a shortfall).
Tips.example: The project ended with a budget surplus.

senses.de: To plan to use a specific amount of money for something
senses.ex: We must budget our resources to last throughout the project

Tips.title: Future Planning
Tips.description: Budgeting as a verb involves planning expenses in advance, not just tracking them.
Tips.example: We need to budget for potential repairs.

Tips.title: Mindful Spending
Tips.description: To budget means to spend mindfully rather than freely, often to save money.
Tips.example: She budgeted carefully to afford her vacation.

Tips.title: Resource Allocation
Tips.description: Using 'budget' as a verb is about both money and other resources like time or materials.
Tips.example: We must budget our supplies for the whole season.

senses.de: low in price; offering good value
senses.ex: The hotel is a good budget option for travellers

Tips.title: Cost-effective Choices
Tips.description: As an adjective, 'budget' often describes options that save money without sacrificing quality.
Tips.example: For budget travelers, hostels are a great choice.

Tips.title: No-Frills
Tips.description: Budget options often have fewer luxuries or added services included.
Tips.example: Budget airlines may charge extra for checked bags.

Tips.title: Perception of Quality
Tips.description: Sometimes 'budget' might carry a connotation of lower quality, but not always.
Tips.example: This budget printer has surprisingly good performance.

Allocate.wordDefinition:
Allocate means to set aside or distribute resources, such as money, time, or supplies, for a specific purpose or task.

It is typically used in a more specific or precise context, such as allocating funds to a particular project or allocating time for different activities.

Budget refers to a plan for managing and allocating financial resources over a certain period of time, usually a year. It is a more general term that encompasses all types of expenses and resources, including money, time, and personnel.

Both words are applicable in different contexts, but allocate is more specific and focused on a particular task, while budget is more broad and encompasses all aspects of financial planning.

Cost.wordDefinition:
Cost refers to the actual amount of money spent on something after it is purchased or used. It is the total amount of money that has been used to acquire or produce something.

For example, the cost of a car includes the price of the car itself, any maintenance costs, and the price of gas used to drive it.

Budget is applicable when you are planning your expenses, while cost is applicable when calculating your actual expenses.

Economize.wordDefinition:
Economize means to reduce your spending in order to save money.

Economizing is more appropriate when you want to save money for a specific goal or if you're facing financial difficulties.

For example, you might economize by cutting back on eating out, using coupons when you go shopping, or finding cheaper alternatives for things you regularly buy.

Overall, budgeting is about managing your money effectively, while economizing is about reducing your expenses in order to save money.

Estimate.wordDefinition:
Estimate refers to a calculation of a cost or quantity that is not exact. It is an educated guess of how much something will cost or how long something will take.

Estimate is applicable when someone wants to have a rough idea of how much something will cost or how long it will take before they commit to a project or purchase.

For example, a contractor may provide an estimate for a home renovation project or a customer may request an estimate on the cost of a car repair.

A budget is a detailed plan for managing and allocating money, while an estimate is a rough calculation of a cost or quantity.

Expenditure.wordDefinition:
Expenditure refers to the actual amount of money that is spent on different items during a period of time.

Then, at the end of the month, they will calculate their actual expenditure by adding up all the money they spent on groceries, entertainment, transportation, and other expenses.

Budgets are applicable in planning and estimating income and expenses for future periods while expenditures are useful in tracking and determining the actual cost of goods and services after they have been purchased.

Finance.wordDefinition:
Finance refers to the management of money and investments over a longer period of time. It involves making decisions about investments, loans, and other financial matters to achieve long-term financial goals.

In simpler terms, budgeting is about planning how to spend your money in the short term, while finance is about managing your money for the long term.

Budgeting is applicable in everyday life when managing personal finances, while finance is more relevant when making investments or managing a business.

Forecast.wordDefinition:
A forecast is a prediction of future events or trends. It is an estimate of what will happen in the future based on current information and trends.

Forecasting is usually used to predict things like future sales or demand for a product.

A budget is a plan for managing your money, while a forecast is a prediction of future events or trends.

A budget is used to manage your finances right now, while a forecast is used to plan for the future.

Plan.wordDefinition:
Budget refers to a financial plan that includes income and expenses. It is a plan to manage your money by tracking your earnings and spending.

A plan refers to a step-by-step strategy to achieve your goals. It is a blueprint for what is needed to be done to reach a certain objective.

Planning is applicable when you want to achieve a specific goal or objective, like finishing a project, travelling to a certain destination, or achieving a certain academic milestone.

In summary, budgeting is a financial plan while planning refers to a strategy to achieve a goal.

quotes.Text: Wyclef is a musician that tried to unite as many musicians at once as possible. I am trying to be successful at that. The greatest challenge is that, I just got arrested for protesting in NYC for cutting the school budgets... And I think that it's important to stand up. Schools are important.

quotes.Name: Wyclef Jean

quotes.Text: As I said a moment ago, there is no higher priority in our budget, or certainly in the budgets of the past few years, than providing for what is needed for the protection and security of our country and support of our troops.

quotes.Text: I'm always attracted to lower budget, not because it's lower budget, but because they tend to be better scripts. It's the scripts that tend to be the small arthouse film that tend to be more actor-led and character driven.

quotes.Text: There's a truth about public service that is often unspoken and rarely understood - that the role of our elected officials is about much more than balancing budgets and ensuring the delivery of essential services.
